pull_requests.title: BIP-383: remove extra stray </tt>
pull_requests.body: Removed an unmatched </tt> tag from the "Multiple Extended Keys" section heading. The extra closing tag had no corresponding opening <tt>, produced invalid markup, and was inconsistent with how other descriptive headings are formatted in BIPs.

pull_requests.title: Draft BIP: Block Size Reduction for Spam Mitigation
pull_requests.body:
## Summary

This draft BIP proposes reducing the maximum block size from 4MB (weight) to 2MB (weight) to mitigate transaction spam and blockchain bloat.

## Motivation

This proposal aims to:
- Limit blockchain growth rate
- Reduce resource requirements for running full nodes
- Prioritize financial transactions over data storage use cases
- Improve network decentralization

## Status

This is an early draft seeking community feedback. As per BIP-02, this should be discussed on the Bitcoin development mailing list before formal consideration.

## Important Notes

- This is a **hard fork** proposal requiring overwhelming economic consensus
- Reduces maximum block weight from 4,000,000 to 2,000,000
- Requires extensive community discussion before any deployment consideration
- May be controversial and requires careful consideration of tradeoffs

## Next Steps

1. Community review and feedback
2. Discussion on bitcoin-dev mailing list
3. Refinement based on technical and economic analysis
4. Further development if there is interest

---

Please note: This is submitted as a draft to initiate discussion. The author understands that significant community consensus building would be required before any such change could be considered for activation.

pull_requests.title: fix: correct misleading ORDER_HALF comment in bip-0374
pull_requests.body:
The comment for ORDER_HALF incorrectly stated it represents "Number of valid distinct x coordinates on the curve". This is wrong - ORDER_HALF is simply half the group order, commonly used for ECDSA low-S signature normalization. The number of valid x coordinates on secp256k1 is approximately (p-1)/2 where p is the field size, which is a completely different value.

Also clarified the ORDER comment from "plus 1 for infinity" to "including infinity" for better accuracy.
